articles.headline: At Stanford, Relationship Reveals Accusations of Discrimination
articles.snippet: A romantic triangle and the dean’s resignation from the Graduate School of Business stir up old and new charges in Silicon Valley about abuses of power.
articles.abstract: A romantic triangle and the dean’s resignation from the Graduate School of Business stir up old and new charges in Silicon Valley about abuses of power.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — He was the recently widowed dean of the nation’s top business school. She was a star professor who was estranged from her husband. They went for a walk. She invited him to a yoga class. A middle-age romance bloomed.

articles.headline: Paul Ryan Says He’ll Run for Speaker if Republicans Unite
articles.snippet: Mr. Ryan addressed his party colleagues and called for a change to the way the job is structured, according to members in the room.
articles.abstract: Mr. Ryan addressed his party colleagues and called for a change to the way the job is structured, according to members in the room.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Paul D. Ryan said Tuesday that he would be willing to serve as speaker if all the factions of his party could unite behind him, giving hope to House Republicans who have been divided by conflict and confusion.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Steinhauer and Emmarie Huetteman

articles.headline: $9.8 Billion Valuation for Ferrari
articles.snippet: The elite sports car maker priced its initial public offering at $52 a share, and will trade under the symbol RACE.
articles.abstract: The elite sports car maker priced its initial public offering at $52 a share, and will trade under the symbol RACE.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, car fanatics have dreamed of owning a Ferrari. Now they can own at least a piece of the company.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Justin Trudeau, Son of a Canadian Leader, Follows His Own Path to Power
articles.snippet: Justin Trudeau chose more difficult roads during his career — partly, it seems, to show he had not been handed a life in politics on a platter.
articles.abstract: Justin Trudeau chose more difficult roads during his career — partly, it seems, to show he had not been handed a life in politics on a platter.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — When Justin Trudeau moves into the prime minister’s official residence, it will be a homecoming. His parents lived there, in the gray stone house at 24 Sussex Drive in Ottawa, when he was born on Christmas Day in 1971.

articles.headline: RushCard Breakdown Affects Thousands of Prepaid Debit Card Users
articles.snippet: The troubles, lasting much of the past week, illustrate the potential perils for those without access to the banking system.
articles.abstract: The troubles, lasting much of the past week, illustrate the potential perils for those without access to the banking system.
articles.lead_paragraph: A woman in Philadelphia was turned away from a McDonald’s when her card was declined. Another woman, in Decatur, Ga., couldn’t pay for her husband’s heart medication. And an autoworker in Detroit accepted food from colleagues because she had no access to her money.
articles.byline: By Liz Moyer and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Hospital Attack Fueled by Units New to Kunduz
articles.snippet: The U.S. airstrike against a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan that killed at least 22 staff members was approved by forces normally assigned to other parts of Asia.
articles.abstract: The U.S. airstrike against a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Afghanistan that killed at least 22 staff members was approved by forces normally assigned to other parts of Asia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The American airstrike against a Doctors Without Borders hospital in northern Afghanistan that killed at least 22 staff members and patients was approved by American Special Operations Forces.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: Police Leaders Join Call to Cut Prison Rosters
articles.snippet: More than 130 police chiefs, sheriffs and prosecutors asserted that “too many people are behind bars that don’t belong there.” The group will meet with President Obama.
articles.abstract: More than 130 police chiefs, sheriffs and prosecutors asserted that “too many people are behind bars that don’t belong there.” The group will meet with President Obama.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 130 police chiefs, prosecutors and sheriffs — including some of the most prominent law enforcement officials in the country — are adding their clout to the movement to reduce the nation’s incarceration rate.

articles.headline: Takata and Honda Kept Quiet on Study That Questioned Airbag Propellant
articles.snippet: The results of Takata-commissioned research on a compound thought to be at the root of an airbag defect were not disclosed to regulators for more than two years.
articles.abstract: The results of Takata-commissioned research on a compound thought to be at the root of an airbag defect were not disclosed to regulators for more than two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The problem had haunted Honda for years: Why were airbags made by Takata exploding in its cars, sending metal fragments flying into the passenger cabin?
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Hiroko Tabuchi

articles.headline: Marco Rubio’s Ambition, and Sharp Elbows, Fueled His Rise in Tallahassee
articles.snippet: Political figures in Florida, supporters and opponents alike, recall Mr. Rubio’s quick ascent in the Legislature, in which he became House speaker from 2006 to 2008.
articles.abstract: Political figures in Florida, supporters and opponents alike, recall Mr. Rubio’s quick ascent in the Legislature, in which he became House speaker from 2006 to 2008.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — In 2000, the man who appeared most likely to become the first Cuban-American speaker of the House in Florida was Gaston Cantens. A former prosecutor and basketball coach for a small Roman Catholic university, Mr. Cantens had amassed a loyal following at home and a solid stack of pledge cards from his fellow Republicans.

articles.headline: Microsoft’s Rule-Breaking Vision of a Future With Countless Devices
articles.snippet: Microsoft is embracing a fragmented view of the future, in which no single device, or even single category of devices, reigns supreme. The plan is rife with risk — but that doesn’t mean it can’t work.
articles.abstract: Microsoft is embracing a fragmented view of the future, in which no single device, or even single category of devices, reigns supreme. The plan is rife with risk — but that doesn’t mean it can’t work.
articles.lead_paragraph: Close your eyes and imagine it’s five years from now. Now, check your pockets and your desk. Which devices are you using?

articles.headline: Paul Ryan Wins Backing of Majority in Freedom Caucus for House Speaker
articles.snippet: As a condition of assuming the key post, the Wisconsin lawmaker urged unity among factions in the fractured Republican Party.
articles.abstract: As a condition of assuming the key post, the Wisconsin lawmaker urged unity among factions in the fractured Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: A strong majority of anti-establishment conservatives in the House Freedom Caucus voted on Wednesday night to support Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin for House speaker, assuring that he will have the votes to secure the post next week and averting a leadership crisis for Republicans.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Emmarie Huetteman
